definition: to revert to old ways
happening/instance/reason/cause/intentional/former/old/friend/therefore/hence/(of people) to die, dead
(bound form)/appearance/shape/form/state/attitude/(grammar) voice
to go and return/to return/to resume/to return to a normal or original state/to repeat/again/to recover/to restore/to turn over/to reply/to answer/to reply to a letter/to retaliate/to carry out
to repeat/to double/to overlap/complex (not simple)/compound/composite/double/diplo-/duplicate/overlapping/to duplicate
variant of 復|复[fu4]/to reply to a letter
to sprout/to bud/to have a strong affection for (slang)/adorable (loanword from Japanese 萌え moe, slang describing affection for a cute character)

sentences.english: He's stop take drug now, but he may revert to take them again.
sentences.chinese: 现在他停止吸毒了，但他可能故态复萌。

sentences.english: But on July 24th, the markets suffered a relapse.
sentences.chinese: 不过在7月24日这天，市场故态复萌。

sentences.english: Relapse is a part of life at Magdalene.
sentences.chinese: 故态复萌是抹大拉从良所生活的一部分。

sentences.english: After a good year the team reverted to type in their last game.
sentences.chinese: 这个队好了一年，上一场比赛中又故态复萌。
莫妮卡童年时爱吃饼干的习惯故态复萌。

sentences.english: You re doing excellent work now I hope you wont backslide .
sentences.chinese: 你现在工作的很好我希望你不会故态复萌。

sentences.english: He kept off drink for a few weeks, but now he has relapsed.
sentences.chinese: 他酒戒了两三个星期，可是现在故态复萌。

definition: see 故態復萌|故态复萌[gu4 tai4 fu4 meng2]
old habits are hard to change (idiom)
old posture/former situation
lit. change to more severe (idiom); to become more intense (esp. of shortcoming)/to aggravate/to intensify
lit. not to change, despite repeated admonition/incorrigible/unrepentant
completely correcting one's former misdeeds (idiom); to repent past mistakes and turn over a new leaf/a reformed character
to rebuke/to blame/to denounce
original identity fully revealed (idiom); fig. to unmask and expose the whole truth
to forget past pains once the wound has healed (idiom)
pinyin: hao3 le5 shang1 ba1 wang4 le5 teng2

definition: chronic illness/old weakness/chronic problem
to calm down/to stop/to pause/calmly/peaceful/restful
old illness recurs (idiom); a relapse/fig. to repeat an old error/the same old problem
to fall out with sb and become hostile
outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
lit. settling accounts after the autumn harvest (idiom); to wait until the time is ripe to settle accounts/to bide time for revenge
confused/mixed up/muddled up/befuddled
